div1.p: Truby uses Vaughan's book, “A Doctor's Memories,” to make reference to numerous events in the yellow fever investigation.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, July 16, 1946
div1.opener:
P.S. Col Richard La Garde & Lawrence Reed are great friends
and I think that they could help you plan some way to get
the note book & other papers from young Carroll. The latter
may look upon La Garde as a
friend.-----
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
July, 16/46
Dear Colonel Hench:-
div1.p:
I am sending herewith my
replies to the Kean questionnaire. I hope
that you will find some things that
will be helpful. The other things I
will send in due time. I have kept
the questions so that if you want to
refer to them I can possibly answer more
questionspoints that may occur to themyou.

What a grand time I had while
you & Mrs. Hench were here! It was
quite unusual for me to be so
active, but I seem to have stood it
very well. We all enjoyed it, especially
the evening at the Mark, Grand.

Your postcard came telling of your fine time
at Santa Barbara came and I am glad
you had such a satisfactory visit with
Houston Lazear. I will be interested in what
info. you got from him. Mrs T. also
had a fine letter from Mrs. Hench. It
was so nice that she could come with
you, and we all enjoyed her visit here.
AC
Tr
What great luck that we had such good
weather. The strange thing is that it has
continued fine. July, you knows, is our
[unclear] most miserable month, with high
winds and [unclear] heavy fogs. To-day was one
of the finest we have had, Most Unusual!

So far, I have not called up Lampon,
but will do so as soon as I get
caught up with things here. If he is
at Sacramento I will call him in Aug.
when he is supposed to be back.

I have been reading “Memories of a
Doctor” again. It is so facinating to
me. Jot down these pages from Vaughan's
book 159 re. Reed, 178 Finlay & Sternberg
and Dr. Cochrane who deserved a “halo”. Also
p. 350, (Guiteras, Echeverria). You ask Kean about
the latter. He was one of the best Cuban Physicians,
and Gorgas used him very much. Also p. 392

You can get a fine picture of the Med. Profession at
the beginning of this Century and the army Med. Dept.
by reading Chapter. X & XI. Col Louis La Garde is my
grand-daughter's great grandfather. If you will meet Col.
Richard La Garde in Washington he can tell you much
about Carroll as it was his father who recommended
Carroll to Reed (See my book (second printing) note, p 107.

When you see him see my other daughter, Barbara
must close now in haste, to get it in the mail.
Best of every thing to you & your fine family.
